name: Tomato mildew
description: Destructive disease causing brown spots on leaves, stems and fruit
symptoms: Irregular brown spots on the leaves
Rapid wilting of leaves
Dark spots on the stems
Fruit rot
White down under the leaves in wet weather

name: Tomato alternariasis
description: Fungal disease causing characteristic concentric spots
symptoms: Brown circular spots with concentric rings
Yellowing and wilting the lower leaves
Spots on rods and petioles
Fruit rot near the peduncle

name: Bacterial tomato spot
description: Bacterial infection causing black spots on leaves and fruits
symptoms: Small black spots with yellow halo
Spots on leaves, stems and fruits
Defoliation in case of severe infection
Frucks cracked and deformed

name: Mildew of the potato
description: The most destructive disease of the potato
symptoms: Aqueous brown spots on leaves
Black rot of tubers
Rapid wilt of foliage
Unpleasant odor of infected tubers

name: Common rust of corn
description: Fungal disease characterized by orange-brown pustules
symptoms: Orange-brown pustules on the leaves
Oval with circular pustules
Leaves yellow
Grain yield reduction

name: Wheat brunette rust
description: Significant wheat disease causing yield losses
symptoms: Orange-brown pustules on the leaves
Circular stains in Oval
Premature yellow
Grain weight reduction

name: Rice pyriculariosis
description: The most destructive disease of rice in the world
symptoms: Gray-brown losang stains on leaves
Lesions on the neck of the panicle
Grains
Breaks

name: Oïdium de la Vine
description: Fungal disease forming a white down on the green organs
symptoms: White powdery down on leaves
White spots on clusters
Leaves
Berry bursting

name: Bacterial pepper spot
description: Bacterial infection affecting pepper leaves and fruits
symptoms: Small brown spots with yellow halo
Liegeous spots on fruit
Severe defoliation
Fruit quality reduction

name: Healthy plant
description: Healthy plant without signs of illness
symptoms: Green and vigorous foliage
Normal growth
Absence of stains or lesions
Healthy root system

overview: Aphids are small, soft-bodied insects that suck sap from plant tissues ...
symptoms: Aphid Feeding Results in an overall loss of plant vigor ...
management: Thoroughly scout crops and wees for signs or symptoms of aphids ...
name: Aphids on Vegetables

overview: Armyworms can be found all over the United States ...
symptoms: Larvae Feed on leaves with Chewing Mouthparts ...
management: Keep Crop Area Weed-Free, Till Residues and Control Wesss ...
name: Armyworms on Vegetables

overview: Blister Beetles in the genera epicuata are found throughout North America ...
symptoms: Adults Feed On Plant Foliage and Blossoms ...
management: Blister beetle populations are influenced by grasshopper populations ...
name: Blister Beetle

overview: Beet Leafhoppers have Wedge-Shaped Bodies Varying in Color from Pale Green, Gray, Or tan ...
symptoms: Adults and nymphs feed with piercing cashparts, which can cause shriveled and 'burned' leaves ...
management: Excluded Leafhoppers with Floating Row Covers, Shade Tomato and Pepper Plants, Remove Plant Debris ...
name: Beet leafhopper

overview: Adults are about the same size and shape as a lady beetle but with Yellow and Black Stripes ...
symptoms: Adults and Larvae feed with chewing mouthparts and can defoliate plants ...
management: ROTATE CROPS TO NON-SOLANACEOUS CROPS, KEEP CROP Area Free of Solanaceous Weeods ...
name: Colorado Potato Beetle

overview: Adult Western Striped Cucumber Beetles Are About 1/3 Inches Long, With Black Heads and Yellow and Black-Striped Wings ...
symptoms: Feeding Scars on Soft Rinds of Fruits, Especially The Undersides. Holes in Stems and Leaves. Destroyed Flowers ...
management: Hand-Pick Cucumber Beetles, Plant Resistant Varieties, Use Row Covers and Mulles ...
name: Western Striped and Spotted Cucumber Beetle

overview: Adults have a black head, legacy, and antennae. They have ovized yellow-green bodies with 12 black spots on the wings ...
symptoms: In hemp, adults chew on leaves, creating irregular-shaped holes. Damage is considering minor ...
management: Keep CROP Area Weed-Free, Use Plastic OR Organic Mullshles, DESTROY CROP Residues after Harvest ...
name: Spotted Cucumber Beetle

overview: Cutworms Belong to A Large Group of Night-Flying Moths in the Noctuidae Family ...
symptoms: Larvae feed with chewing mouthparts and can clip off seedlings at the soil line ...
management: Remove Cool-Season WEDS, USE FALL TILLAGE TO Exhibits Overwinting Pupae, Protect Seedlings With Collars ...
name: Cutworms on Vegetables

overview: On adults, the head, thorax, and anterior portion of the wings are brownish gray and the posterior portion of the wings are whitish-clear ...
symptoms: Adults and Nymphs Feed With Piercing-Sucking Mouthparts. Large Numbers of Aggregating Adults can cause Plants to Wilt and Die Rapidly ...
management: Scout Field Edges that may contain Mustards, look for aggregations on plants, keep plants well irrigated ...
name: False Chinch Bug

overview: Flea beetles are common and problemmatic in utah, affecting vegetable crops and ornamental plants ...
symptoms: Small, round holes or pits in leaves and cotyledons ...
management: Adjust Planting Times, Healthy Plant Growth Promote, Use Trap Crops and Row Covers ...
name: Flea Beetles

overview: Adults are large Moths also nown as sphinx, hawk, or hummingbird moths. Larvae are Large, cylindrical and usually green ...
symptoms: Larvae use Chewing Mouthparts to Feed On Leaves, Blossoms, Stems, and Fruits, Leaving Behind Dark Green Or Black Frass ...
management: Plow Field after Harvest to destroy Pupae, Rotate crops with non-host plants, handpick larvae at dawn or dusk ...
name: Tomato and Tobacco Hornworms

overview: Thrips overwinter as adults in plant debris and protected areas. In the Spring, They Become Active and Move Into Fields ...
symptoms: White Flecks or Silvery Scars on Foliage, Dark Fecal Spots on Leaves, Distorted Leaf Growth, Reduced Bulb size in Onions ...
management: PLOW Plant Debris Under After Harvest, Transplant Inspect for Thrips, Remove Weeeds Within Fields, Place Mulch, plant resistant crop varieties ...
name: Thrips on Vegetables

hosts: Weeds Including Pigweed and Shepherd's Purse
overview: Adults are Wedge-Shaped, Light Green in Color, and Widest at the Head with an Elongated Body ...
symptoms: Adults and Nymphs Feed with piercing-sucking Mouthparts, Causing White-Flecked Injury (Stippling) on ​​Foliage. Heavy Feeding can lead to scorching ...
management: Manage Weeds to Reduce Leafhopper Populations, Monitor Symptoms Such As Curling Leaves and Stippling, insecticide application when necessary ...
name: Potato leafhopper

overview: Adults are tiny, with a yellowish-clear body and two dark spots on eith side of its back ...
symptoms: Stippled (Small Yellow Spots) Leaves, Generalized Bronzing Or Reddish Discoloration, Reduced Plant Vigor, Premature Leaf Drop ...
management: Keep Plants Healthy, Wash Mites Off Plants With Strong Water Stream, Avoid Malathion and Pyrethroid Insecticides, Attract Predatory Mites ...
name: Two-Spotted Spider Mite

overview: Corn Earworm Larvae Feed On All Plant Parts, included Fruits and Kernels. Damage can result in decreased pollination and hollow-out fruits ...
symptoms: Tunnels in Kernels and Fruits Filleted with Frass, Direct Damage to Stems, Foliage, and Corn Silk, Premature Fruit Ripening, Fruit Rot ...
management: AVOID PLANTING SOLNACEUS CROPS CROPS NEAR Post-Silking Corn Fields, Use Clothespins on Corn Silk, Plant Resistant Varishes, Remove Infested Plant Debris ...
name: Corn Earworm / Tomato FruitWorm

overview: Adults and nymphs have cigar-shaped, yellowish-tan or pink bodies and require a microscope to observe ...
symptoms: Bronzing or 'Russeting' of Stems, Leaves, and Fruits, Yellowing, Curling, Deflated Leaves, and Longitudinal Cracks on Fruits ...
management: Use clean transplants, avoid planting during hot, dry periods, remove infested debris, clean tools after ...
name: Russet Tomato Mite

overview: Adults are tiny with bright white wings and yellow-orange heads. Immature internships are pale, transluent, and most motionless ...
symptoms: LEAVES Turn Yellow, Appear Dry, or Fall Off Plants. Whiteflies also excrete honeydew, causing sticky surfaces or sooty mold Growth ...
management: Attract and keep Natural Enemies, transplant inspect, Remove Heavoy Infested Plants, Use Biocontrol Such as Boursia SP ....
insecticides: clarified hydrophobic extract of neem oil
name: Whiteflies (Family: Aleyrodidae)

overview: Alfalfa Mosaic Virus (AMV) is in the genus alfamovirus and is spread by aphids ...
symptoms: Yellow Mosaic or Calico patterns on foliage, Stunned Plants, Tuber Necrosis, Bright Yellow Interspersed with Green ...
management: AVOID POSTATOR POTATOES OR HEMP Near Alfalfa Fields, Remove Plants With Positive Diagnosis ...
name: Alfalfa Mosaic Virus

overview: BACTERIAL CANKER DIREE is caused by clavibacter michiganensis subsp. Michiganensis. It is primary an Economic concern for tomato ...
symptoms: Wilting in Young Plants, Yellow Leaf Margins ('Firing'), White Spots with Dark Centers on Fruit, Vascular Discoloration in Stems ...
management: Source Disease-Free Seed, Clean and Disinfect Equipment, Avoid Overwatering, Rotate Crops, Remove Solanaceous Weeds, Deep Plow Soil ...
insecticides: COPPER-BASED Products Effective in Greenhouse Transplant Production
name: Bacterial Canker

overview: Bacterial Speck (Pseudomonas Syringae Pv. Tomato) Infections Occur During Cool (63 to 75 ° F) Wet Conditions ...
symptoms: Brown to black spots with a yellow halo on leaves, scabby pinpoint-like spots on fruit, damage does not penetrate into flesh ...
management: Start examining undersides of leaves soon after planting, delay planting unit wet pass conditions pass, avoid overhead irrigation, rotate crops ...
name: Bacterial Speck

hosts: Several Other Wild and Economic Hosts
overview: Beet Curly Top Virus (BCTV) is a curtovirus in the geminiviridae family, vectored by the beet leafhopper (blh) ...
symptoms: Young Infected Plants Usally Die, Stunned Growth, Thick Curled Leaves, DUL Yellow Color with Purple Veins, Prematurely Ripened Fruit ...
management: Implement shading, use row covers, double plant to reduce losses, manage wees that serve as alternative hosts for blh ...
insecticides: Avoid Chemical Treatments due to blh migration
name: Beet Curly Top Virus

overview: Big Bud is caused by A Small Bacterium Called Phytoplasma, Infecting Plant Vascular Tissue and Causing Abnomal Growth ...
symptoms: Swollen Flower Buds, Distorted Flower and Leaf Growth, Short and Thick Apical Stems, Yellow Discoloration of Foliage ...
management: Remove Infected Plants, Clear Weeds that host leafhoppers ...
name: Big Bud

overview: Blossom-End Rot (BER) is a physiological disorder caused by calcium deficiency and aggravated by month Imbalances ...
symptoms: Water-Soaked Discoloration on the Blossom End, Leathery Dark Bruown or Black Lesions, Sunken Fruit, Potential Secondary Infections ...
management: Use Deep, Infrequent Irrigation to Mainain Uniform Soil Moisture, Avoid Ammonium-Based Nitrogen Fertilizers, Protect Roots from Injury, apply Mulch ...
name: Blossom End Rot

overview: Damping-off is caused by soilborne organizations included pythium, rhizoctonia, fusarium, and phytophthora species ...
symptoms: Circular Bare Spots in Seed Flats due to seedling Death, Pinched Brown or Black Stems, Seedlings Tipping Over ...
management: Disinfect Growing Benches and Containers, Use Sterile Potting Mix, Excessive Avoid Irrigation ...
insecticides: Seed Treatments available, Fungicides can reduce incidence
name: Damping-off

overview: Early Blight is a Fungal Disease Caused by Alternaria Solani, Mature Vines, Tubers, and Fruit ...
symptoms: PINPOINT Brown or Black Spots On Lower Leaves, Yellow Halo Around Spots, Concentric Rings in Lesions, Sunken Stem and Tuber Lesions ...
management: Use crop rotations, transplant-free source-free, destroy volunteer plants, Plow Down Debris, Plant Plant Vigor, Avoid extended leaf Wetness ...
insecticides: Fungicide spray programs initiated in early august if lesions appear
name: Early Blightt

overview: Fusarium species causing this diSease are soilborne pathogens that persist in soil for years ...
symptoms: Rotting and Necrotic Roots, Discoloration and Soflanting of Crown Tissue, Stunned Growth, Wilting and Plant Death ...
management: Remove Infected Plants, Sanitize Equipment, Sterilize Soil, Rotate Crops with non-sispible varieties, sure proper soil drainage ...
insecticides: Available no fungicides, prevention is key
name: Fusarium Crown/Root Rot

overview: Fusarium Wilt is caused by fusarium oxysporum, with formae specials specific to individual crops ...
symptoms: Foliar Chlorosis, Wilting, Red to Purple Leaf Discoloration, Stunned Growth, Brown Vascular Tissue, Reduced Yield ...
management: Use certified disease-free seed, plant resistant varieties, improve water drainage, clean Equipment to minimize spread ...
insecticides: No Chemical Controls available, Prevention is Key
name: Fusarium Wilt

overview: Late Blight is caused by Phytophthora Infestans and Spreads Rapidly Under wet, moderate temperatures ...
symptoms: Greasy-Gray Blotches on Leaves and Stems that turn black, Hard Brown Blotchy Lesions on Fruit and Tubers Extending Into Flesh ...
management: Scout Early After Planting, Monitor Wet Field Areas, Eliminate Infected Plant Debris, Avoid Overhead Irrigation, Rotate Crops ...
insecticides: Fungicides needed where the ditease has occurred in the past
name: Bright

overview: Microscopic RoundWorms that Entered Through Root Tips Plants, Moving Within Roots Until they Find Préferred Feeding Spots ...
symptoms: Chlorosis, Stunning Resembling Nutrient Defectory, Galled Roots that May Merge Into Large Tumors ...
management: Use tolerant varieties, Keep Infested Fields Fallow, Remove Weeeds, Roto-Till Fallow Areas Regularly, Apply Telona Fumigation in Commercial Fields ...
insecticides: No chemical options available for non-commercial fields
name: Root-knot nematodes

overview: Caused by Various Phytophthora Species, Thriving in Water-SATURATED SOIL AND INFECTING PLENT ROOTS ...
symptoms: Bruised, Soft, Rotted Seedlings, Chocolate-Brown Lesions on Roots and Stems, Yellowing Leaves, Wilting and Plant Death in Patches ...
management: Watch for Symptoms Early, Improve Soil Drainage, Manage Water Use, Rotate Crops, Use resistant varieties ...
insecticides: No Chemical Control, Prevention through water management
name: Phytophthora Root, Stem, and Crown Rots

overview: Powdery MILDEW IS Easily Identifiable As White, Powdery Patches on Leaves. It thrives in warm temperatures, humid canopies, and poor airflow ...
symptoms: White, Powdery Fungal Growth on Leaves, Stems, and Petioles; Yellowing and Wilting of Leaves, Potential Fruit Sunscald and Yield Loss ...
management: Plant resistant varieties, Remove Infected Plant Material After Harvest, Improve Air Traffic, Use Morning Irrigation, Switch to Drip Irrigation ...
insecticides: Available Fungicides, Repeated EVERY APPLICATIONS 7–10 Days
name: Powdery Mildew on Vegetables

overview: TMV and Tomv Are Tobamoviruses Spread by Seed, Grafting, Human Handling, and Tobacco Products ...
symptoms: Abnormally shaped fruit, fruit lesions, reduced fruit size, distorted growth points, yellowing leaves, stem distortion ...
management: Remove Infected Plants IMPOSIALY, Source Disease-Free Seed, Grow Resistant Varishes, Disinfect Tools, Avoid Tobacco Handling ...
insecticides: No Chemical Controls available, rely on sanitation and resistant cultivars
name: Tobacco Mosaic Virus & Tomato Mosaic Virus

hosts: Several Other Vegetable and Weed Hosts
overview: Tomato Spotted Wilt Virus (TSWV) is a tospovirus spread by thrips species and affects plants throughout the growing season ...
symptoms: Stunned plants, necrotic leaf spots, calico patterns on mature fruit, necrotic rings on fruit, discoloration of seeds ...
management: Monitor Thrips Activity, Remove and Destroy Infected Plants, Purchase Healthy Transplants, Use resistant varieties, Control Weeds ...
insecticides: No Chemical Controls Available, Rely on Thrips Management and Resistant Cultivars
name: Tomato Spotted Wilt Virus

hosts: Many Crop, Ornamental, and Weed Species
overview: Verticillium Wilt is caused by fungi verticillium dahliae and verticillium albo-atrum, persisting for years in soil ...
symptoms: Leaves Yellow and Die from the Bottom Up, Decreased Fruit Quality, Premature Wilting, Symptoms Appearing On One Side of the Plant ...
management: Use resistant varieties, plant on raised beds, avoid planting in infed field, prevent root injury, sanitation practitioner, root crop ...
insecticides: No direct Chemical Control, rely on prevention and resistant cultivars
name: Verticillium Wilt

overview: Caused by Cercospora Capsici and C. Melongenae, Producing Circular Chlorotic Lesions with Necrotic Centers ...
symptoms: Small Chlorotic Lesions, Necrotic Centers With Concentric Rings, Defoliation, Reduced Fruit Size ...
management: Use Protectant Fungicide Spray Programs, Remove Infected Debris, Rotate Crops, Apply Mulch, Use Furrow or Drip Irrigation ...
insecticides: Fungicide Treatments Based On Calendar Schedule
name: Cercle Leaf Spot (Frogeye)

overview: Caused by Choanephora Cucurbitarum, occurring in Tropical Regions with High humidity and rainfall ...
symptoms: Water-Soaked Areas On Leaves, Blighted Apical Growing Points, Dark Gray Fungal Growth, Silvery Spine-Like Fungal Structures, Black Soft Rot in Fruit ...
management: Few Management Available; Fungicide sprays May help reduce Damage ...
insecticides: Limited Fungicide Options, Rely on Environmental Control
name: Choanephora Blight (Wet Rot)

overview: Caused by Stempylium Solani and S. Lycopersici, leading to small red to brown spots on foliage ...
symptoms: Expanding Lesions with White to Gray Centers and Dark Margins, Yellowing Leaves, Defoliation, DES NOT Affect Fruit ...
management: Remove Infected Plant Debris, Improve Ventilation for Seedlings, Apple Fungicide Treatments ...
name: Gray Leaf Spot

overview: Caused by Phomopsis Vexans, Affecting Seedlings, Leaves, Stems, and Fruit, Leading to Significant Plant Decline ...
symptoms: Dark-Brown Lesions on Stems, Dry Rot, Collapsing Seedlings, Circular Gray-Brown Lesions on Leaves, Severe Defoliation, Mummified Fruit ...
management: SOW HIGH-QUALITY SEED, Remove Infected Plants, Rotate Crops, Mulch and Furrow Irrigate to Reduce Pathogen Spread ...
name: Phomopsis Blightt
